hasVariant.description: Buy the PEARL iZUMi Expedition Bib Short - Women's online or shop all Bike from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: Are the other reviews paid for by pearl izumi or just made by people who do 20min rides because these are the worst & most uncomfortable bibs Ive ever worn. Made the mistake of wearing them first the first time on a 3+hr ride and I am in so much pain. Do not recommend these, would give zero stars.
review.name: Horrifically uncomfortable

review.reviewBody:
Super high quality - compared with the pro version, these are just as great IMO. I loved these so much I bought 3 - I mountain bike a lot and do XC/long distances so I use them quite a bit and there is nothing else I would rather ride in. The pockets - TWO pockets on each thigh, lovely size (can fit a Poptart without breaking it!), a phone, snacks, etc. The material is stretchy and comfortable. I don't think about these. THE PULL DOWN MECHANISM is amazing to drop down and pee without taking them off! GAME CHANGER. Also, I wish more bibs would be in that sage encore color - black gets too hot!!! Seriously, I love these bibs. 

I am a size 8 and usually wear medium but these are just perfect in size L.
review.name: I CAN'T LIVE WITHOUT THESE!!!!!!!!!!!!

name: Expedition Bib Short - Women's

description: Buy the DMM Pivot Belay Device online or shop all Climb from Backcountry.com.

hasVariant.name: Pivot Belay Device
hasVariant.description: Buy the DMM Pivot Belay Device online or shop all Climb from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: The pivot was my first belay device and still my go-to. Pretty standard compared with ATC guide or reverse with the exception that the pivot makes lowering a follower much easier.
review.name: Best tube device for lowering followers

review.reviewBody: Works perfectly with Clepsydra S carabiner, both in normal belaying and guide mode. The huge hanger hole is surprisingly nice for rotating a biner through if you've used the smaller opening on an ATC. It's just slightly less fussy, does not get stuck on barrels. The release hole is compatible with smaller noses on biners like other belay devices, it doesn't work with BD HoodWire gate biners or WC Heliums, though can also use a dyneema sling.
review.name: Works great

name: Pivot Belay Device

review.itemreviewed: Camber Original Classic Fit Pant - Men's
review.reviewBody: Been looking for 100% cotton Khaki pants to work in for quite a while now. I'm really glad I found these. They are well made, look great, and are super comfortable. I realize they're not ideal for hiking or backpacking as they are cotton, but I bought them for work, so they're perfect. I also like the cell phone pocket, it's perfect for an I-phone in a case. I purchased these on sale, so I got them for less money than the crappy dept. store type. I highly recommend these pants, especially for work, or just knocking around town.  I listed that they run large, but only because of the length, the waist sizing (for me) was spot-on. You can probably deduct an inch, for the length. I normally wear a 34 length, but 33, in these pants was perfect.
review.name: I love em

name: Camber Original Classic Fit Pant - Men's

hasVariant.description: Buy the Gregory Facet 45L Backpack - Women's online or shop all Hike & Camp from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: I purchased this pack as a lightweight and smaller option for weekend trips. I have the diva 60 and love it for bigger trips with a heavier pack. So far I have used my facet 45 on a 3-day hike in the Grand Canyon. I absolutely love it! I think I will be using this much more than my bigger pack for weekend trips! My load only ended up being about 25 lb but it felt like I was carrying nothing! I love that the hip belt is long enough to wrap all the way around my hips. This may be an issue for smaller hikers. I am 5'10 and weigh 125 lb. With a loaded pack the hip belt was as tight as it goes but I was able to get it just as tight as I needed! Any smaller and I'd have a hard time getting it as tight as I want. I was also surprised how tall the medium was for me! I have a hard time getting packs that are tall enough since I have a long torso. This pack fit me perfectly! I had enough room up above to use the shoulder straps to take some weight off of my shoulders. This pack seems to be the perfect balance between comfort and lightweight! I love the springy trampoline feel around my back. I hike a lot in the desert so having air flow between my back and my pack is important to me. The pack had just enough pockets to keep me organized. I love that a water bottle can slide into the side pockets and be accessed easily while walking. The material seems high quality and it seems like it will last me for many years of hiking! Highly recommend!
review.name: Great lightweight pack!

review.reviewBody: I loved this pack so much I carried it all the way from Georgia to Maine on my 2024 Appalachian Trail thru hike. I swapped the brain for the rain flap to save weight, as the Facet is a happy medium between UL and trampoline framed packs. The materials are hydrophobic and didnt require a pack cover with my dry stuff in a dynema pack liner. Although 45L inside, this bag swallows an enormous amount of gear and its thoughtful design made it easy to pack and carry for 6 1/2 months. I didnt need to carry a bunch of stuff outside of the pack because everything fit, and its low profile made it easy to squeeze through tight spaces without taking it off. I could easily access water bottles from the side pockets on the move with everything cinched tightly thanks to the stretch mesh pockets being outside of the side straps. The hip belt pockets held ample snacks, headphones, pepper spray, sanitizer, gum and fits a pro max iphone. Even though i was dragging it on rocks and other trail abuses, the materials are durable and held up. The only downsides were the perimeter frame would sometimes squeak if I overloaded it way past the 30lbs maximum (a reminder to not resupply hungry!) and I wish the hip belt on the M/L could get smaller. I washed it twice with dish soap in a bathtub when the straps got too stinky, but this pack had noticeably less funk than what others in my trail fam were carrying. Polygiene for the win! Overall, the Facet/Focal is an underrated but exceptionally comfortable and durable bag for long-distance backpacking. I am 56 with a 17 torso and the M/L fit like a glove which is weird for a pack. I would take it again and look forward to future adventures with this pack.
review.name: A Thru Hikers Dream!
comment: Thanks for taking Gregory on your long haul.

review.reviewBody: I bought this pack to upsize from my  GregoryJuno 30 for desert tortoise survey work. I LOVE that it comes in extra small to fit my short torso.  It was comfortable enough to wear for 8+ hours/day and fit all my required gear. I did feel some discomfort while carrying 4 liters of water plus gear for long distances but this may have been more of a personal problem than a problem with the pack or its fit- I felt fine after dropping to 3 liters or less. The hip belt pockets provided enough room for  a leatherman, sunscreen stick, chapstick, and lens wipes. The belt straps seemed a bit long, but better too long than too short.  I liked that I could clip my GPS unit to the elastic loop on the shoulder strap (not as ideal as the loop on the juno 30 strap, but still worked). My hydration bladder did not fit perfectly on the rservoir hanger hardware, so it took some extra effort to get in and out of the pack, but it was worth not having to buy an entirely new reservoir. Since this bag is meant more for backpacking, it had fewer organizing pockets than a standard daypack but worked fine, especially with separate ditty bags for some of my gear. The side mesh water bottle pockets were a strength- they seemed durable and could be loaded either from the top or at an angle to make it easy to reach in while walking. I feel like the ventilation gap helped me stay cool in the desert heat.  Overall this is a great pack and I'd definitely recommend it for use as an outdoors work bag.
review.name: Durable and comfortable

review.reviewBody: [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Great sturdy pack! Comfortable to carry - true fit. Plenty of pockets to stay organized, especially with the hip belt pockets! The mesh side pockets are large enough to hold two water bottles in one pocket if needed. The bladder is great. I put it in the hydration pocket and fed the hose through to my front and put the magnet on the opposite pack strap, it worked perfectly. I dislike the adjustable loops on the bottom of the pack to hold your tent or sleeping pad. It was difficult to push my tent through the loops, it would make more sense to have buckles on the loops to easily open and adjust them. It's also hard to adjust them since they feed through to where the water bottle mesh pockets are so you would need to remove your water bottles to adjust while on the trail. I also dislike the extra opening on the mesh water bottle pockets. If I am packing light I usually only take one pocket for an extra water bottle and the other pocket to store things I want to access easily while I am walking like my phone, snacks, camera, etc - things that are too big for the hip belt pockets. Some things would stay in the pack but when I took it off and set it down they would fall out of that extra hole. I know some people prefer this style of pocket so maybe it could be an option when choosing your pack?
review.name: Great smaller pack

name: Facet 45L Backpack - Women's

review.itemreviewed: Speedgoat 6 Mid GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's
review.reviewBody: I'm not hiking or running with them. I'm chasing middle school kids all day!  As a SPED teacher on my feet all day, these saved my feet! #teacherlife #spedteacher #feetrelief
review.name: This footwear is of exceptional quality.

review.itemreviewed: Speedgoat 6 Mid GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's
review.reviewBody: I have issues with the ball of my right foot and high arches. I am super pleased with the comfort of the SG6. Logged about 15 miles in 2 days on pavement. This weekend will try them off road. I'm looking forward to it.
review.name: Super comfortable!

review.itemreviewed: Speedgoat 6 Mid GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's
review.reviewBody: Velcro in place of ankle pads . Can't lace up tight due to the new configuration .i hated them as soon as i put them on. Speedgoat 2 is the GOAT! Turn back the clock!
review.name: Worst version of speedgoat mid gtx.

review.itemreviewed: Speedgoat 6 Mid GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's
review.reviewBody: Took them on an 80 mile hike in Silverton and wow was I disappointed. I've bought dozens of speedgoats over the years. The insole is paper thin, it's almost non-existent. Felt like walking on concrete. I've never my entire life had pain in the arch of my foot, but these shoes crushed them. Highly recommend getting something else.
review.name: Too firm

review.itemreviewed: Speedgoat 6 Mid GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's
review.reviewBody: Ordered a size 10. But no where near size ten like my previous models of Hoka shoes. Also, Were these a product return from another customer?
review.name: Speedboat GTX mid

review.itemreviewed: Speedgoat 6 Mid GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's
review.reviewBody: Ordered a pair for an upcoming cold weather/rainy season trip. The SG6, as many others have noted, is a totally different shoe than the SG5, with a much firmer midsole; I knew that going in. The issue with these is the placement of the laces; they are entirely too low for a mid-height shoe. The last eyelet is at below-ankle height, which is (I'm sure) the eyelet height of the SG6 lows. The neoprene booty (which Velcros into place) is flimsy and offers no additional support. Thus, the shoe wears like a low top with an extra incongruous piece of material attached; it's as if they just slapped the neoprene booty on the SG6 low and called it a day. The pictures make the shoe look like it ties higher up on the foot/ankle, but due to the stack height, that's not the case. Depending on your foot shape, you might require a half size smaller.
review.name: Good in theory, poor execution.

review.itemreviewed: Speedgoat 6 Mid GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's
review.reviewBody: Genius of design, with a band to lock out any pebbles and debris, plus Goretex and the most incredible soles and overall fit. Hoka is crushing the competition. They used to make bouncy / over-cushioned shoes, but now offer a huge variety of Hiking shoes and carbon plate soles as well. The Vibram sole waterproof, sturdy layer is a true game-changer. I will never buy a pair of On Running again. No comparison
review.name: Wow what a shoe! Hoka are real pros

review.itemreviewed: Speedgoat 6 Mid GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's
review.reviewBody: I thought the soft mid would be weird but I absolutely love it. I wear a 13 and my feet splay pretty wide naturally. These fit my feet perfectly and the soft mid actually helped lock my heel into place. I usually have heel slip issues with Hokas but these are a 10/10 for me. Side Note: Also, tried the standard SG 6's and they fit completely different. The SG 6's squeezed the living daylights out of my feet. Not sure if that's how they are designed to fit or if there are some QC issues. Nonetheless, I'm still content with my Mid versions.
review.name: Perfect fit!

review.itemreviewed: Speedgoat 6 Mid GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's
review.reviewBody: I have been looking forward to the Speedgoat Mid redesign for two year now and I can honestly say this is so disappointing! Neoprene? And Velcro?! No apparent actual ankle support...why?
review.name: Honestly Heartbreaking Design Changes

name: Speedgoat 6 Mid GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's

review.reviewBody: Incredibly flattering! I have four colors. This is one of my favorite products from this brand!
review.name: Awesome!!

review.reviewBody:
The perfect jacket for adventures and around town! I use this for mtn biking, hiking, camping, or running errands. The fit is wonderful, great freedom of motion, and it washes up perfectly!

First bought in black, loved so much had to get one in green also!
review.name: Perfect Jacket

review.reviewBody: I bought this last summer and it has gone on many adventure with me . it's nice as a standalone hoodie or is that perfect layer for winter activities on colder days . it is rugged and still looks nice with lots of wear . no pilling ! I like the black on the bottom
review.name: great features

review.reviewBody: This jacket is very nice and is well designed.  However, being advertised as a 'technical fleece that will keep you warm at high elevations' is generous as the material is so very, very thin.  Like, I get that it's supposed to be for layering, etc., but legitimately, I wear thicker t-shirts.  Ultimately it was returned.
review.name: Too expensive for what it is

review.reviewBody: I bought this hoody in Deep Forest in my usual size of medium. The colour is fabulous. This style of fleece fits snug and I only have room for a thin baselayer underneath. Depending on how you want this to fit consider sizing up. The thumb holes make it easier to layer over. I am 5'6 150lbs with an athletic build.
review.name: Nice layering piece, fits snug.

review.reviewBody: Finding your favorite layers when in the backcountry is key! This is apart of my go to quiver for backcountry skiing. Its breathable while offering protecting from the cold. Also great for layering under a heavier puffy. Definitely rely on this as a great option for a mid layer over a base and under and heavier down for summit snacks before the descent!
review.name: Great add for your layering quiver

review.reviewBody:
This feminine multi functional hoodie is a great "go to" for so many activities that I am involved with. I mainly use this for when I am mountain biking, as it is fitted and keeps you warm when it is a bit chilly and cool when it is too hot, as it is made of two differently produced fleece materials. This is for all year around!
Martina S
review.name: Be a fox!

review.reviewBody:
I love this zip up hoodie for getting sweaty in - It has breathable fabric all over, and extra light mesh on the back and arms (T-zone) for extra moisture wicking. 
The fit is flattering, I am 5'8" and wear a Large W. 
I also bought one for my partner, he is 6'3" and loves the size Large M. 

Kelly A.
review.name: Athletic Style for your workout!

review.reviewBody: There always seems to be a black hoody that I gravitate towards. And this one has been it since I got it. Love the zip pockets and the weight of the fleece. Warm and cozy as a ski mid-layer. Breathable and comfy over a t-shirt too. I wear this all the time and could probably go for another color....
review.name: Favorite hoody

review.reviewBody: This is my go to piece for a jacket type layer in warmer months and a mid layer during the winter. The chest pocket is spacious enough for a phone. I'm 5'5" 115lbs and had trouble deciding between the small or xsmall. Ultimately, I went with the XS for a snugger fit. It washes well. I haven't noticed any change in fit or appearance. I wish it came in more colors!
review.name: The perfect mid-layer!

review.reviewBody: My initial thoughts on these boots after riding in them for a bit are that these are really comfortable and responsive boots. The Cloud 9 liners are crazy comfortable and the boots feel pretty great on my feet right out of the box. The Dual BOA feature is great and it allows you to easily dial in your preferred tightness and adjust them on the fly if needed. And the Vibram sole gives you great grip on the boot pack or if you're just walking around the resort or parking lot.
review.name: Really Comfortable!

review.reviewBody: The ankle brace is really good but the boot is really narrow.
review.name: Too narrow, nice support

review.reviewBody: I'm sure they are a good boot but the width changed to be narrow.  I've had 5 pair of other Salewa climbing boots over the years (3 models) and all were a perfect fit. Just got these and the fit is so narrow it hurts. Even putting on a thin sock and removing the insole didn't really help.  I don't think I can wear these. Probably will return them if they can't be stretched out.
review.name: Too narrow, fit changed from other boots
comment:
A very good day Ian Lauder,

Thank you for taking the time to review the Ortles Couloir Men's Boot.

I am very pleased to read that you already own more pairs of the boot but that the fit of the new pair is too narrow. Unfortunately, no changes were made in production and therefore the fit should be similar to the other models.

I will pass this on to my colleagues in production so that the fit of the shoe can be reviewed.

I wish you an eventful day
Your Salewa Team
#puremountain

review.reviewBody: These boots are incredible for mixed and ice climbing. They also work well for general mountaineering. Unlike the other reviewer I found the sizing perfect. The boots walk exceptionally well, better than any other boot I've ever tried, if you leave the Velcro strap at the top off. If you use the Velcro strap the boots don't walk as well. The boots climb incredibly well for ice and mixed and they're crazy light. After a few hours of using them though they do start to get a bit uncomfortable. Which raises an interesting point, I also own the Mammut Nordwand High Knit boots and those are more comfortable but don't climb as well, they still climb amazing just not as good as these. I wouldn't pay retail for these, and if they're not on sale I'd consider the Mammut boots instead of these but if these are discounted I'd probably go with these.
review.name: Incredibly light and warm

review.reviewBody: [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Der Carbonschaft ist zwar gut gedacht, allerdings bleibt man mit dem Carbonschaft, wenn man zu eng geht hngen und gert so in Sturzgefahr. Hier muss eine andere Lsung gefunden werden. Man muss den Karbonschaft oben abdecken damit so etwas nicht passieren kann. Zudem denke ich, dass es auch mglich ist den Schuh ohne Karbonschaft zu bauen.
review.name: Sehr leicht, gute Passform, gute Sohle, wasserdicht
comment:
Einen schnen guten Tag Peter Veider,

vielen Dank, dass Du Dir die Zeit genommen hast, die Ortles Couloir Schuhe zu bewerten. 

Es freut mich sehr zu lesen, dass der Carbonschaft gut gedacht ist, jedoch kann die Gefahr entstehen, dass man am Carbonschaft hngen bleibt. 

Ich werde dies an meine Kollegen in der Produktion weitergeben, damit der Schaft verbessert werden kann.

Ich wnsche Dir einen erlebnisreichen Tag

Dein Salewa Team
#puremountain

review.reviewBody: Love this boots, returned them because of the size.  About 1 number up to fit u well with the socks.
review.name: Too small!

name: Ortles Couloir Boot - Men's

review.reviewBody: Had to return these shorts cause of the strange sizing. I'm 6'3 200lbs and the waist was perfect in a size small but the thighs and seat of the short were much too tight... Just not a short model that is gonna work for me.
review.name: Sizing a bit off

review.reviewBody: The size small is a bit loose in the waist which should be a problem except that the belt doesn't work. It loosens after a few strides. It's also sewn in but there are only two belt loops so replacing it will take some customization. Don't buy if you are planning on a functioning belt to keep them up.
review.name: Belt is bad

review.reviewBody: First of all I love Chilli Lite Shorts! I have around 8 pairs. I just recently bought the red oaks. Unfortunately, the color in person looks nothing like the color online. I sent them back and as usual Backcountry makes it easy and was refunded within days.
review.name: Red Oak

review.reviewBody: Loose fit, half-elastic waist short with logo shank button and fly zip, built in belt, half-moon pockets with right rear internal wallet stay, gusset, thick thread and double needle reinforced seams.
review.name: KAVU Chillie Lite Short

review.reviewBody:
I climb and cycle, and 4 things really bother me about these shorts:

(1) The front hand pockets are weird and flimsy
(2) Not a big fan of the velcro on the rear pockets
(3) The material is not as hefty or durable as described
(4) Loose threads upon receiving the item and some of the stitching has already come undone

If the front pockets were stitched  onto the shorts they would feel better and be less flimsy. The way they are now, the front pockets shift around too much, feel a little too flimsy, and can show underneath the hem of the shorts. Just a lil annoying.

And to me the velcro on the rear pockets are unnecessary because the pockets are deep and secure enough on their own.

Despite all of these things, I still like the shorts. They get the job done.
review.name: Nice but can be better

review.reviewBody:
I climb and cycle, and 4 things really bother me about these shorts:

If the front pockets were stitched  onto the shorts they would feel better and be less flimsy. The way they are now, the front pockets shift around too much, feel a little too flimsy, and can show underneath the hem of the shorts. Just a lil annoying.

And to me the velcro on the rear pockets are unnecessary because the pockets are deep and secure enough on their own.

Despite all of these things, I still like the shorts. They get the job done.
review.name: Nice but the pockets fall short

review.reviewBody: I am a size 32 waist so I purchased the small (32-34?). They fit true to size around my waist, however they were skin tight around my thighs. If you weight lift, be sure to order a size up, unless you like that look.
review.name: Too small for athletic legs

review.reviewBody: I am very particular about cotton flannel. One of my preferences is the weight. I like a mid to heavy weight flannel. I just believe anything less defeats the purpose. But, that's me.  This shirt is actually exemplary in most respects, except weight. Now, if you don't have the same preference that I do, then maybe you'll consider a a 5-Star rating. I give it 4 stars. It fits perfectly. It is super soft. The stitching is flawless. The colors pop - for now anyway!
review.name: Great Fit... Soft... but

review.reviewBody: Bought these on final sale. They were too small, so I asked to exchange for one size up. Didnt ask for (or want) a refund. These boots run extremely small. They refused the exchange, so I now own boots I cant wear. Will not do business with them again. Very disappointed!
review.name: Im stuck with boots that dont fit!

review.reviewBody: Perfect boots!!! So comfy! Went a half size up and so happy I did! Thanks to reviews.
review.name: Great!

review.reviewBody:
**Review: Sorel Chelsea Bootie**

I recently purchased the Sorel Chelsea Bootie, opting for a size up to achieve a wider fit, and I'm thoroughly pleased with my decision. The boots fit perfectly, with no rubbing or discomfort, and the extra room allows for thicker socks if needed.

Having purchased Sorel boots before, I've consistently found that going a size up works best for me, and this time was no exception. The sole of the boot is particularly impressive, offering excellent grip even in wet conditions, which is a huge plus. The boot itself is soft and comfortable right out of the box, making it a reliable choice for daily wear. Highly recommended!
review.name: Outstanding little Bootie

review.reviewBody: I got the black/gum version and never have gotten so many compliments on a pair of shoes. And I thought they were just black boots!!
review.name: Compliments all day

review.reviewBody: I really wanted these boots to work but they just didn't for me. I ordered true to size (I have a few SOREL footwear products and true to size is always on point). For some reason these boots were extremely tight (I do not have a wide foot either), and the heel was so uncomfortable pushing into it, it hurt. I didn't even want to try breaking them in because I know for a fact I would have gotten blisters from doing so. So I returned them and will hopefully be receiving a merchandise credit here soon. Bummer, but I will get a different pair of shoes with my refund anyways. Thanks!
review.name: Cute but Uncomfortable. Had to Return
comment: Hello Chelsea, we appreciate you sharing your feedback and we're sorry Women's Hi-Line Chelsea Boot didn't meet your standards. We will inform our product team of your concerns and ensure this is fixed for the future.

review.reviewBody: Great look, comfortable, break in quickly, warm but not too warm

Comfy, warm, and dry. Mostly, I love not having to tie shoe laces when I need to run outside on a rainy/snowy day! They were a bit snug when I first slipped them on, but have loosened up a bit with wear.
review.name: Goodbye shoelaces!

review.reviewBody:
I ordered this boot on January 15th. It took over a week to ship it and rhe delivery itself was then rescheduled. It got to the point that I was concerned I would have to contact my bank to get my money back, which is not a nice feeling. They did arrive and were well packaged but I wouldnt recommend ordering in a hurry.
Now for the boots. I would describe them as fitting a little smaller than expected, with a low rise. I am normally a size 36 EU and ordered a 37EU as I have a wide foot with a high arch. The boot itself looks well made and is surprising light, which I like. It looks great on and I look forward to using it once Ive worn it in.
review.name: Nice boot

review.reviewBody: I have had these for a winter or two now and I love them! They wear well, are versatile, clean easily, and are very comfortable!
review.name: Love them!

review.reviewBody: Stylish, lightweight and comfortable! So hard to find a Chelsea boot with all those requirements
review.name: 10/10 Chelsea boot

review.reviewBody:
Besides the weight and the price, I did love most things about this bag when I got it. The built in stand makes it super easy to get the bike broken down and setup as well as getting it locked in place once it is in the bag. 

The problems started when I actually started checking the bag. On the very first trip it came off the conveyor belt with a big gash in the side. Now on my third trip one of the corner assemblies that holds one of the rear wheels on is gone leaving a huge hole in the corner of the bag and only one wheel to roll on. the side handle strap has also started to rip off with a big chunk of the side fabric. 

Thankfully there hasn't been any damage to the bike, but now without that rear wheel it is impossible to move around when loaded. THULE denied my warranty claim because they are saying they only cover manufacturing defects. My mistake for thinking "Roundtrip" would mean it is good for more than one round trip.
review.name: Not Durable Enough for Air Travel

review.reviewBody: Backcountry is working with us to make this right, this is not a review against backcountry, instead for Big Agnes.  I love Bog Agnes, but must have got a bad clamp for the main tent.  But I have faith that Backcountry will make this right.
review.name: The tent clamp broke on its own.

review.reviewBody:
Its my first tent,  and my friend have the same one so i tested it before got mine.
Ultralight, easy to set, good looking, and solid made!
review.name: Big up!

review.reviewBody: I originally bought this tent because I wanted something to trade out my old heavy tent for something lighter. Let me tell you this thing is awesome! The set up is super easy, and it's extremely light weight. The poles are durable and strong. Luckily the poles come with an infield repair splint which I haven't had to use yet. I purchased the footprint separately and so far, I don't have any holes or wear in the tent or footprint, but I am also extremely cautions with where I am setting up for the night, looking for rocks, sticks, etc. that might poke a hole. The rain fly performs its function perfectly. The only complaint I have may be that the cross pole can be pretty difficult to get in place. I paired this tent with the Big Agnes floor pad, and it fits perfectly!
review.name: Best tent I own!

review.reviewBody:
This is my fourth Big Agnes product failure (4 purchases out of 4).  Two sleeping pads failed shortly after purchase, one deemed a manufacturing defect and the other was a material defect.  I was able to get a refund from where I purchased them.  Next up was a Fly Creek HV UL failure.  BA credited me for that and thats how I ended up with the Copper Spur HV UL2.

The Copper Spur was relatively stable and stayed fairly dry in moderate wind and rain conditions.  As I have experienced with ALL BA tents, it is virtually impossible to zip the rain fly shut with one hand when dry due to relentless snagging, and it absolutely requires two hands to zip the fly closed when the fabric is wet and limp, and has the consistency of saturated tissue paper.  After one season of moderate use, one rain fly zipper failed and the zipper would not stay closed and continuously split open.  To remedy this, BA required me to pay shipping AND pay for a replacement zipper pull, even though I asked that they replace the entire zipper (I was willing to pay for it though they insisted the zipper was AOK).  After it was returned to me (at my expense) the zipper pull was so tight it was almost impossible to close the rain fly on that side so I quit using that side.  Finally, I just returned from a long bike packing tour in Mongolia where I experienced a full on meltdown.  On this trip, the other rain fly zipper failed and then shortly after that, BOTH tent zippers failed, they would split open and not stay closed.  This was particularly frustrating during a torrential downpour in a very remote area that also had quite a few insects.  No functional tent zippers and no functional rain fly zippers.  Rain and bugs in the tent.  By this time all of the shock cords in the tent poles were also weak and would not hold the poles together.  We detoured to a larger town where I could find a replacement tent.  My only option was a cheap Chinese tent, but at this juncture I had no alternative.  Given that I was on a bicycle and had another month of riding ahead of me, I couldnt carry two tents, and had not choice but to jettison the defective Big Agnes tent.  Aside, the $60 Chinese tent worked perfectly for the next two months of daily use in a variety of harsh and moderate conditions.

Bottom line, there are 4 Big Agnes products that I purchased that are now buried in landfills somewhere that never even came close to reaching the end of a useful life.  Sickening.  Big Agnes clearly doesnt support their products and isnt concerned about making quality outdoor equipment that will last for a reasonable period of time.  I will never consider any BA product in the future and there are plenty of alternatives produced by companies that are ecologically minded and manufacture products that last including Nemo, Marmot, Hilleberg among many others.
review.name: My Worst Product Experience Ever

review.reviewBody:
I did a lot of research before buying a tent, and every single website I came across for tents recommended this as their number 1 pick. All of them, no exceptions, which is kind of mind boggling.

After using this tent all summer for my backpacking trips, I can see why. This tent is very light for backpacking. It's also very easy to assemble, as well. A little color coding that it uses goes a long way and saves time.

In terms of durability, well, it's held up very well. Last night (literally, last night), I slept in it through a rain storm, and I kept perfectly dry and couldn't feel any gusts of wind at all. It was a shockingly comfortable night of sleep out in the woods in a rain storm.

I would also say it's a solid size. When I slept in the thing with someone else, I did wish there was more room, but I always had just enough. The internal pouches it has too are very convenient. There's a big one above your head, and then a small one on each side for each person, so you can store things that you might need in the middle of the night, like a head lamp. There's also a loop in the center of the tent you can use to hang something, and I always hung a lantern there.

I have some minor complaints though. Ingress and regress with the rain fly on just sucked. All the time. I wished that if you unzip the rain fly you could just stand up from there, but I always had to crawl out on my hands and knees before I could stand. Also, the zippers just out-right suck. They are flimsy and I had one break on the rain fly, and all of them, even the ones in the tent, get caught or require a significant amount of force to close.

I don't know how durable this tent is in the long term, over the span of years. It is rather thin because it is so light, but it seems to be holding up quite well after this summer, so I think as long as you're careful, you'll be okay.

Despite my complaints and worries, and its hefty price, I'm very glad this is the tent I used this year. It did its job when it mattered most, is very light, has just enough space, and is very easy to put together. I now know why it is the king tent for backpacking.
review.name: And Then Humanity Was Blessed With This

review.reviewBody: I purchased the BA Copper Spur HV UL2 Tent: 2-Person 3-Season (so many words- why?) as an upgrade to my old NF Firefly backpacking tent from the nineties for a week-long backpacking trip along the CDT through the Wind Rivers in June. It's amazing... The test run night (an aborted trip from Battle Pass- too much snow) we set it up on boggy ground at 10,600 ft and stayed dry all night. At Big Sandy Lake, the tent kept us dry and cozy while it rained from 7am to 2pm. For the rest of the trip through the Winds, the tent held up through heavy winds at Little Seneca Lake where we tied the guy lines to any available tree, and a long night of rain between the Green River Lakes where it did develop a slight puddle on top (but no leaks). But even better than its ability to keep us completely dry and cozy is its capability as a laundry room. Clever loops throughout the inside of the tent allowed us to string up our rotating sets of wet socks and other unmentionables. The large mesh pockets held our sodden boot insoles and allowed our damp pants' legs to "dry" overnight. We particularly liked the fly zip set-ups which opened two ways for easy escape while keeping the tent dry. Also- both sides have doors, so no creeping over each other to come and go. And it's light. So light. The flip side is that the loops inside and the loops to hold the fly open feel delicate. Just treat it gently. And use the footprint. Overall though, this tent  just makes me happy.
review.name: It's a Keeper...

review.itemreviewed: Lofoten GORE-TEX PRO Plus Jacket - Men's
review.reviewBody: This jacket is amazing! High quality build with great features. Zips are all well placed and easy to operate. The rear arm vents are not mesh lined as advertised. If you are a smedium then you are a medium in this brand the measurements are exact to the charts. No wiggle room in the torso. Had to swap a S for an M to be able to layer properly.  Really nice hood, access to interior chest pocket through vent is killer feature as is the vent on chest itself!
review.name: Top notch

review.itemreviewed: Lofoten GORE-TEX PRO Plus Jacket - Men's
review.reviewBody: This is a serious quality jacket, with a fatal flaw. The wrist/cuff Velcro tabs are tiny! If I am wearing this jacket, I am in stormy weather w/ most likely warm mittens/gloves. Good luck on adjusting the cuff tension with this tiny velcro tab. Total fail on the design side. I opted for a Mammut Nordwand Pro HS jacket with oversized cuff tabs. Otherwise the jacket is top quality, but runs large in comparison to most manufactures. The front zip ventilation is genius, but the Mammut jacket fits my athletic build better :0)
review.name: Wrist cuff velcro tabs are tiny!

review.itemreviewed: Lofoten GORE-TEX PRO Plus Jacket - Men's
review.reviewBody:
This has a more dense weave than the regular pro jacket. The pro version is 70 denier feels like old school goretex, plastic like and thin. The pro plus has a more durable, thicker weave (70/140 I think), which makes this jacket feel more like light weight canvas. I believe they even say the pro plus is a lighter jacket if that's possible. 

For the extra money, the pro plus gives you pack friendly hand pockets, tricep vents which are incredibly easy to use, and a slightly longer cut with a 2 way zipper. All of those extras are worth it. What seals the deal is the front zipper that's mesh lined and has velcro opening to your under layers. It makes getting into your bib pockets and getting a beacon out so easy. With the zip open, it provides amazing breathability without getting snow inside and is enhanced if you open the tricep vents. You get wonderful cross air flow and it's suitable for skinning. On top of that, there's even pit zips for maximum heat dump age. In a storm with the hood up, you can still breath through the mesh and it seriously helps prevent goggle fog up. 

Skied 3' of fresh with 50 mph winds in the backcountry off Wolf Creek Pass and then rode the resort with a lot of hiking. Lots of bushwhacking and branch strikes. Never took the layer off to skin, never had fogged goggles, never had wet clothes, never had a rip. This pro plus jacket with Gore Tex Pro is also the most breathable Gore Tex made to date, and it really, really works! Coupled with all the venting options, this jacket (along with the heavier duty matching pants) are bomber, lightweight and handle diverse conditions extremely well. I've done lots of resort skinning and backcountry with the jacket/bib combo, and it's the best I've ever used in 40 years of winter activities with heavy exertion. 

For the most part it's true to size. I'm very fit with a 46" chest. The XL fits perfect, although the bicep area is a little large. Lots of room for thick fleece or a puff underneath. Not too baggy with a light layer either. 

The price is high, and higher than Arc'teryx for example, but I really appreciate Norrona's sustainability platform, material sourcing, and recycled Gore Tex. The trim, materials, and options make it worth it for me.
review.name: Amazing, breathable, durable

review.itemreviewed: Lofoten GORE-TEX PRO Plus Jacket - Men's
review.reviewBody: I purchased this jacket after purchasing Norrona's gtx pro plus pants (which are frankly one of the best ski pants I have ever owned), as they form a perfect combo. The features on this jacket are second to none. However, the fitting is wayyyy off. I purchased a small, but it is so long that the jacket goes all the way to my mid thigh. The sleeves also run quite long, and are baggier than I would prefer. I would advise sizing down.
review.name: Amazing jacket, but runs too large

name: Lofoten GORE-TEX PRO Plus Jacket - Men's

review.reviewBody: Post came on certified pre-owned XC race bike.  From the start had problems.   Clamp is horrendous. Like the other reviewer, clamp came lose during multiple ride(s)/race(s) then pointed the seat up. Had to stop and punch the seat nose down.  After I did this, there is no adjusting the angle because the clamp will not stay tight, and seat gets wobbly and unpredictable.  Had to go to hardware store for a fix, which did not remain permanent.   Avoid!
review.name: Horrible

review.reviewBody: It goes up and down, but has so many issues. The seat clamp is awful. I tightened it to spec and it came loose and sent the seat straight up in a ride. I had to tighten it down to keep it from injuring me, now I can't adjust the saddle angle at all. It has a lot of play both left to right and back and forth. I've only ridden it twice, and it's been a major negative factor on both rides.
review.name: Bad dropper

review.reviewBody:
I have used Kask Helmets for the past 10 years and love them.  Fits great just like all my old ones. I have always loved the leather strap on the helmet one of the selling points for me since I really dislike the fabric straps on my chin. 
Bought Medium.

5'10"
185 lbs
32 waist
32 Length
42.5 Shoe Size
7 1/4 (22.75 Circ) Head.
review.name: Fits Well and Comfortable

review.reviewBody:
Product Review: KASK Valegro Helmet - A Perfect Blend of Style, Comfort, and Safety

When it comes to cycling gear, one item that should never be compromised is a reliable and high-quality helmet. As an avid cyclist myself, I understand the importance of finding a helmet that not only offers maximum protection but also delivers on style and comfort. After extensive research and testing, I am thrilled to present my review of the KASK Valegro Helmet - a true game-changer in the world of cycling helmets.

First and foremost, let's talk about safety. The KASK Valegro Helmet is designed with utmost attention to detail and incorporates cutting-edge technology to ensure your head is well protected during every ride. The helmet is constructed using a durable polycarbonate shell that provides excellent impact resistance, giving me peace of mind knowing that my head is well shielded against any potential accidents.

One of the standout features of the KASK Valegro Helmet is its impressive ventilation system. When cycling under the scorching sun, overheating can be a major concern. However, this helmet's design incorporates a staggering 37 ventilation holes strategically placed throughout the helmet. This ensures optimal airflow and breathability, keeping my head cool and comfortable, even during long and grueling rides. The effective ventilation system also helps in wicking away sweat, preventing any discomfort or irritation.

Fit and comfort are crucial factors when choosing a helmet, and the KASK Valegro Helmet surpasses expectations in this department. The Octo Fit retention system allows for easy adjustment and customization to achieve the perfect fit. The helmet feels snug and secure on my head, without any uncomfortable pressure points. Moreover, the interior padding is plush and soft, providing additional comfort and absorbing any impact or vibration during bumpy rides.

When it comes to aesthetics, the KASK Valegro Helmet truly shines. The sleek and streamlined design, available in a variety of vibrant colors, makes a bold statement on the road. Whether you prefer a classic black or a more vibrant red or blue, there is a color option to suit every cyclist's personal style. The helmet's overall design is aerodynamic, reducing drag and enhancing speed, making it an ideal choice for competitive cyclists.

Another noteworthy aspect of the KASK Valegro Helmet is its lightweight construction. Weighing in at a mere 180 grams (size medium), it is one of the lightest helmets available on the market. This lightweight design not only adds to the overall comfort but also minimizes strain on the neck and shoulders during long rides. The helmet feels barely noticeable on my head, allowing me to fully focus on my cycling performance.

In terms of practicality, the KASK Valegro Helmet has some impressive features. The chin strap is easily adjustable and secures the helmet in place without any discomfort. Additionally, the helmet is equipped with an anti-bacterial padding that is removable and washable, ensuring hygiene and freshness even after extensive use. KASK has also included reflective stickers on the rear of the helmet, increasing visibility and enhancing safety, especially during low-light conditions.

Having tested the KASK Valegro Helmet in various weather conditions, I can confidently say that it performs exceptionally well. The helmet's durable construction and excellent ventilation make it suitable for both hot summer rides and chilly winter escapades. It offers reliable protection and comfort all year round, making it a versatile choice for cyclists in any climate.

In conclusion, the KASK Valegro Helmet is a remarkable piece of cycling gear that ticks all the boxes - safety, comfort, style, and practicality. Its superior construction, lightweight design, and effective ventilation system make it a standout choice for cyclists of all levels. Whether you are a professional racer or a casual rider, this helmet is a worthy investment
review.name: A Perfect Blend

review.reviewBody: If possible, try it in person before ordering online to make sure it's the right fit for you. Used the sizing chart and the helmet fit perfectly however as others have mentioned, the side straps' length/positioning are not adjustable and were pulling up and into the bottom of my ear lobes. I purchased a size M and have "normal-sized" ears. I could see how this would be a great helmet, especially in warm climate riding, however the lack of customizable fit makes it a bit of a crapshoot
review.name: If Possible, Try In Person

review.reviewBody:
As other reviews mentioned, the side strap "V" length and position are not adjustable, so it may fit very well, or not so well, depending on your head size and shape. For me, the V was too long, placing the buckles right at my jawline, which was not comfortable.

The thick synthetic leather chin strap is a nice touch, but can't be easily shortened, unlike thinner nylon straps. When I tightened the chin strap the extra strap stuck straight out about 2 inches past the retaining loop, not a great look for a helmet strap.

As for size, I was just at the size break for S/M, but the small was way too small, definitely order the medium if you're between sizes.

Weight is just ok for a helmet advertised as super-light. The small is 230 grams, the medium is 250 grams. While still light, these weights are significantly higher than the weights you'll see in many reviews for the lighter EU helmets, made to a lesser safety standard than the US CPSC standard. I guess an extra 40 grams is worth it if it saves your noggin.

This is a stylish, well ventilated and well made helmet, but the fixed side straps were a deal breaker for me. There's certainly a lot less fiddling to get the helmet fitted, but only if  those fixed straps work for you.
review.name: Not A Good Fit For Me

review.reviewBody:
I've never owned a Kask helmet before.  Over the years, I've owned helmets from Giro, Specialized, Bell, Catlike, Uvex, Orbea, and Mavic.  None of those helmets were poorly made, and they all seemed to be made to pretty much similar standards, quality-wise.  I was surprised, then, that this Kask helmet is, to my eyes, clearly manufactured to a higher standard.  The polystyrene mold lines and in-shell molding are very clean and crisp, with no apparent misalignments.  The graphics are all on straight and are either dyed/painted or sublimated on.  The straps feel of very high quality with clean, crisp stitching.  Really well-made.

I got this helmet to replace/supplement a Mavic Comete helmet, that I just bought several months ago (which itself was a replacement of a quite old Orbea Odin).  The Comete was fine, but whether due to the implementation of the MIPS or otherwise, I found it quite hot (despite its claims of excellent airflow) and that its browpad would quickly become saturated and dump significant amounts of accumulated sweat into my glasses, even on relatively cool days (think mid 70s).  It was annoying enough that I got the Kask as a lightweight, long and hot ride helmet.  

Despite the Kask helmet not having a browpad (it does come with an optional stick-on pad, which I've not used), the airflow off the forehead keeps my glasses relatively dry, other than the occasional small drip when its really hot.  The helmet is very light and very well ventilated.  The lightest and best ventilated helmet I've ever owned, I think, though the Catlike and S-Works helmets were close.  The pleather chin strap is surprisingly comfortable and very easy to use and adjust.  An added bonus is that it stays where it is adjusted, unlike nearly all my other helmets.  The helmet's y-straps just clear my earlobes and lie flat perfectly.   While it works for me, I can see the non-adjustable y-straps potentially being a problem for someone with a larger head (I measured my head at about 59 and 3/4 cm around and am wearing a size L).  

But, the helmet is not perfect, even for me.  The retention system's vertical adjustment does not lock into place, which means that every time I put on and take off the helmet, it needs to be adjusted.  Sometimes, when I go from just cruising on the hoods to sprinting in the drops (and thereby changing my back/neck angles) I hear a click or two of the vertical adjustment moving.  Also, as others have mentioned, the lack of a brow pad and the thin padding does lead to some pressure points at the front/top of my head.  About 20 miles into my first ride with the helmet, it was a real problem, until I backed off the dial of the adjustment system by a click or two.  That resolved the problem on that ride, and pretty much every ride since.  As a result, the helmet doesn't feel as "locked down" as many other modern helmets, but it still feels relatively secure on my head (and doesn't seem to shift or move just in normal riding).
review.name: Extremely well-made, but not perfect.

name: Valegro Helmet

review.reviewBody:
I like a little more support and these are killer slippers for that. Handles smears like a dream but still provides support on awful little holds. 
Toebox feels a little small but I have a wide toebox
Heel is normal
Rubber is super sticky and super thick. This will be my main gym shoe and should last a long time.
review.name: Excellent slippers

review.reviewBody: This is my go-to for everything except my projects. I use them to train, multi-pitch, crack climb, boulder, sport, trad - you name it. It might not be the best for any one thing but is good enough at everything. Even with recent price increases, it still seems like a great deal.  I'm now on my third (or fourth?) pair.  I wear a size 11-11.5 in street shoes. I find the Up Mocc size 9.5 US to be the best balance of comfort and performance for me.
review.name: Best Shoe for the Best Price

review.reviewBody: Personally, I think it is quite true to size. I do not think it runs large in any capacity. I did not feel the fabric stretch much. If you are a beginner, these will take a while to adjust to but well worth it! Buy your street shoe size if you are a beginner, it is working great for me!
review.name: Great beginner shoe!

review.reviewBody:
As a self claimed slipper connoisseur, these are just the best. After the OG Five Ten moccs (little red rockets) were changed, I searched far and wide for the next best thing. The Up Mocc is IT. Sized appropriately, these have a fantastic performance aspect to them that a lot of slippers get wrong. The heel will actually hold most heel hooks, unless you really need to crank on a small edge. The toe is much more precise than other slippers and translates well to small edges without sacrificing smearing performance. The toe rubber is an added bonus for toe hooks.

I sized down 1 full size from street and have found them perfect. They are slightly tight to begin with, but stretch nicely. The toe rubber prohibits too much stretching in the upper and keep the shoe performance oriented. A issue I've found with past slippers is that the upper will stretch too much with lots of wear and performance will fade. Time will tell, but so far no concerns with overstretching on the upper due to the added toe rubber. 

BUY THEM NOW!
review.name: One Slipper To Rule Them All

review.reviewBody:
Really great slipper and overall climbing shoe. Comfortable enough for trad and sticky enough for relatively hard bouldering. Used them on some overhung routes that and stuck to holds that only my dragos have stuck to before. Look elsewhere if you need to heel hook though. 
Sized .5 below my street shoe for a comfortable fit but can be fitted 1. - 1.5 for a more aggressive fit.
review.name: Great slipper

review.reviewBody:
I've worn it for over a month and I have to say this is my new favorite all-around shoe. 
I have low-volume feet and got a full size down (9.5) from my street shoe (10.5) and it is perfect after a week or so of breaking them in. 
It has a surprisingly soft sole and a super large toe patch for toe hooking. I've bat-hung on long indoor roof routes many times with confidence.
However, it does have some flaws. It has a thick 4mm rand and there is almost no sensitivity at the toe. Not a dealbreaker for me but for some this is the case.

Regardless, if you consider I got this for around 115$, I think the pros defintely outweight the cons. For comparison, it is basically priced like an LS finale. 

In conclusion, buy one before they raise the price!
review.name: Best balance of performance and price

review.reviewBody: I found my new casual trad/crack comfort shoe. Sized 1/2 size below street shoe size. Great for cracks and moderate trad routes. Rubber is sticky even on smooth basalt and plastic gym holds. Heel is surprisingly secure for a mocc style shoe. They appear to be quality. They are very soft/flexible so you better have strong feet if planning long days or a lot of edging.
review.name: Best mocc style shoe

review.reviewBody: I used to be in the ruby slipper cult like many of you, but I was disappointed when the manufacturer changed hands and the shoes weren't the same. After a period of lamentation and a couple resoles I set out to find a new slipper and find it I did. The Unparallel UpMoccs are everything my ruby slippers were and more. They are as comfortable as a climbing shoe can be with a great suction fit right out of the box ( I wear a street 8.5/9 and bought 8 moccs). Good sticky rubber that excels at smearing/scumming/hooking. No more baggy achilles' heel like the old red moccs and more rubber coverage on the forefoot for toe hooking and foot jamming. Sure you could have a more aggressive shoe for the steep or a stiffer shoe for micro edging but all in all a great shoe for multiple styles of climbing. Hopefully other slipper lovers will discover wonders of the UpMocc as well and they'll be available long into the future. I'm currently in the market for a new pair of lace ups and I know where I'm looking first.
review.name: Ruby slipper killer

name: Up Mocc Shoe

review.itemreviewed: Children Of The Gnar Snowboard - 2024 - Kids'
review.reviewBody: Was in the market for a new board (shorter) that i can hit the park with and still have fun cruising the slopes. Capita Children of the Gnar is an awesome board that worked out well for me. I'm not that tall, and its harder to find a shorter mens board that compliments my type of riding style. I  usually like riding the shorter boards to control it better, and this one did not disappoint even though it's a kids board. It holds and handles my riding style perfectly! its fun and playful, yet sturdy enough to hold weight. the flex is reasonable for ground tricks and butters, so im really happy with it so far!
review.name: GNAR-LY

name: Children Of The Gnar Snowboard - 2024 - Kids'

review.reviewBody: Swell boots at another swell price.  Thank you, Ariat, from the tips of my toes to the top of my head.
review.name: Darlin Ariat Ankle Boots

review.reviewBody: Ordered 2 more pairs of Ariats . They came out n last night . I got a pair of these Darlins & the Sterling Cora.  Christmas  Present for myself. I am in love with them. The colors are amazing & the fit is great too. Ariat is my go to brand for boots  now.  13 pairs is a bit of an overkill or obsession. But I love wearing them and a girl has to have a different pair for whatever outfit shes wearing.
review.name: Awesome !! Peace, Love & Ariats

review.reviewBody: The boots are good quality boots, but I had problems with finding the correct size for these. I currently own a pair of HERITAGE R TOE WESTERN BOOT in 8.5 C Wide, that fit perfectly, so ordered the same size in these!. They were way too tight, so exchanged for next size up 9 C Wide, which were also too short! I placed the size 9 C Wide in these next to the boots I have and they are visually at least an inch shorter. I have not tried to go another size up. If you have wide feet, I would go a whole size up in these!
review.name: Great boots, but sizing does not match HERITAGE R

review.reviewBody: Good quality bootie. Very comfortable and runs true to size. I like the style of this bootie because it does not have the sides cut out and they do not rub against my ankles. I have been an Ariat boot fan for a long time and this style does not disappoint.
review.name: Looks just like the pic

review.reviewBody: Love these, so comfy. Got them in black and brown and would buy more in other colours. Perfect length which looks great with jeans, leggings, skirts or dresses. Easy to get on with side zip. Highly recommend.
review.name: Soooo comfy

review.reviewBody: These boots are very good looking with jeans and dresses.
review.name: Love these boots!

review.reviewBody: Love my new boots.. They are perfect for dresses or pants. I did get the wide because boots are always tight on my thick foot and they fit perfect!
review.name: Great boots

review.reviewBody: These are way too narrow.  I ordered the wide because the other two standard width boots are a little on the snug side.  The wide in these is more narrow than my other boots.  Absolutely loved the style, but sad I couldn't keep them
review.name: Wide is too narrow
comment: We strive to deliver great product and service, so were sorry to hear you were disappointed. If you are willing to share more feedback on how we can help, please email info@ariat.com so that we can better assist you.

review.reviewBody: These arrived today, they seemed on the tight side at first but after my first wear they are beginning to feel really comfortable. Colour (sassy brown) was lighter than expected but overall really pleased with them. Think these are going to be my go to boots this winter!
review.name: Great boots - colour lighter than expected.

review.reviewBody: I bought these boots recently and they are easy to wear, look amazing and are very well made. High quality leather and stitching makes them durable. They look good with dresses and tights or jeans or leggings
review.name: Stylish, comfortable and well made boots

review.itemreviewed: Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System
review.reviewBody: Awesome stove.  Bought this o connect to m first one.  Now I have four burners.
review.name: Jet Boil Genesis

review.itemreviewed: Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System
review.reviewBody: The stove is great, good heat and efficient.  The pots that come with are a great size, however, could be more sturdy.  The straining top for the pot CANNOT be use on the pan as it will cause it to melt.  It would be great to have it able to be used with both included cooking surfaces.  The wind shield is also not the best.  Wind shield helps to protect the flame, however, does not protect the cooking surfaces resulting a lot of loss of heat to those surfaces in the wind.
review.name: Great stove - Want to Love it

review.itemreviewed: Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System
review.reviewBody: The Genesis system packs up into a small, fairly lightweight package.  It is super easy to use to be able to cook an amazing camp meal.  The ability for the different pieces to nest inside one another makes it where you never forget pieces.  Overall the usability of it is top notch and what you would expect from JetBoil.
review.name: Exceptional Product

review.itemreviewed: Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System
review.reviewBody: The product is sleek in design and super portable. Easy to store and easy to break out for a trip. My only complaint would be the dials. They spin freely making it challenging to gauge where the gas comes out at an optimal place.

review.itemreviewed: Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System
review.reviewBody: Pricey, but easily one of the best camp cooking system on the market!

review.itemreviewed: Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System
review.reviewBody:
Awesome product design with great flame control. Easy to use, great for campsites and base camps. Would not want to carry into the back country.  

While I only used one burner for my meal, I did test out running both burners at the same time.
review.name: Great for Truck Camping

review.itemreviewed: Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System
review.reviewBody: Been wanting one of these for a while, will be perfect for deer camp and extended days hiking.
review.name: Base camp

review.itemreviewed: Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System
review.reviewBody: The stove and its contents store perfectly. Live that I can use and adapter to hook up to my 20 lb propane bottle and the griddle fits right on it for breakfast.
review.name: Compact stove

review.itemreviewed: Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System
review.reviewBody: I miss my Basecamp. 7 National Parks hiking and writing ( sequel to my National Treasure Movie franchise) It was all packed up and stored in my Jeep and unfortunately "it was borrowed" while I was out on the trail. Someone will be cooking well tonight. Great stove and very space saving. Easy to operate. Decent precision flame adjustment. (critical for chef wife) Most likely will be ordering a new one! May add the extra burner!
review.name: No Clues Needed

review.itemreviewed: Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System
review.reviewBody: Build quality, plus the fine adjustment from simmer to boil. I love the fact I can use two full size skillets, cant do that with the Coleman stoves I have used in the past.

name: Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System
Genesis Base Camp 2 Burner Cooking System

review.reviewBody: Many great ideas in this bag (dedicated avy tool pockety, bright color inside pockets for increased visibility, nice size goggle pocket for essentials) however some of the functional parts  of the bag fell short. The largest pocket in the bag is accessible from the back and the top but from the top the zipper only opens as wide as the where the top buckles come across, making it pretty much useless. The hip belts also have A LOT of extra belt...I had to really wrap it around the belt to hide it/get it out of the way it was hanging down so much. These two misses in design lead me to return the bag.
review.name: A few updates needed

review.reviewBody: I'm a big fan of these new GE900 MTB shoes. Pretty simple design that checks all the boxes of what I was looking for in a shoe. The boa system combined with the top strap is cinches down tight for the climbs and is quick to loosen after the ride or when you need a relief from feet swelling a bit. The toe box is ample and well protected as I've already scrapped them up a bit from taking on a few unavoidable rocks. The ankle liner works well to keep the schmutz out. I did go with my actual size and they are slightly smaller than I thought which initially had me wearing thinner socks as thay broke in which is good for the heat but might not be my favorite if I was wearing with super thick socks or with wool and neoprene as some do for long winter adventures. Not for me. After a couple of rides, These are so much more comfortable than any other shoe I've used in the past. I will leave them on to mow the lawn after I get back from a ride without even noticing. I'm running them with crank bros mallet pedals which has been a winning combo for me.
review.name: So Far So Great.

review.reviewBody: Ok, so partly writing to say the Shimano's recommendation to size down is wrong. I have ME-7s in 46 and previous in 45.5 when they offered half sizes and I got a 45 and like every Shimano 45 I've tried the last 10 years it was too small. I'd say stick with your normal Shimano sizing. That said, like the M7s these felt perfect out of the box. They are a tad more flexible than the me7. They are not bulky or narrow and keep that sweet low stack height, keeping your foot close to the clear plate. They have enough volume to add an insert, if you need arch support. The engineering in Shimano shoes is just so consistent and awesome. I would have preferred laces but the GE9 doesn't have the annoying ankle protection the GE7 has. And the boa plus strap is actually well done and provided a secure fit. Whether these are the shoe for you is subjective... But they did a solid on this design. Follow the size chart and you should be fine.
review.name: Shimano shoes rock

name: GE900 MTB Shoe - Men's

review.itemreviewed: Cyklon Cross GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's
review.reviewBody:
I've logged over 200,000 lifetime running miles so needless to say I've gone through more than a few pair of shoes. That said, I'm currently logging miles at altitude on mountain trails that are rocky and sometimes icy and/or snow covered.

These shoes really hold their own and dare I say exceed expectations - now here comes the "but" part - but they seem to run at least a half size small. I ordered size 42.5 (US 9.5), my usual but they were a bit snug and add to that the insoles in them were so flimsy I opted to remove them and put in something a bit more substantial...

That really put me up against it, the end of the shoes that is but since I'm not a big fan of returning things I've simply rolled with these. After all, I'm old and slow these days and after so many miles, I don't sweat the small stuff, pun intended...

Ending on a bright note, the BOA lacing system coupled with the zip up "closure" ensures these will stay on your feet (exactly how you want them to) and further, I've yet to have even the smallest rock or anything else for that matter get into these because when they're on, they're on!  And yes, the traction is great and your feet will stay warm and dry in these...

Footnote: While it was a different model, I was able to try on a La Sportiva trail shoe cut similarly to these and found that size 43.5 (US 10) gave me just enough room to swap out the insoles like I did with my Cyklons and still have a little breathing room...
review.name: Great shoes but...

name: Cyklon Cross GTX Trail Running Shoe - Men's

review.itemreviewed: Riff Endless Promise 30 Sleeping Bag: 30F Down
review.reviewBody:
Used the 15F in -16C while camping in my truck cap. I used a fleece blanket over top as I had the space but nightly I was unzipping the lower zipper as I was cooking! 
Im a side and stomach sleeper and this bag lets you move without without the mummy bag claustrophobia!
review.name: Did the job!

review.itemreviewed: Riff Endless Promise 30 Sleeping Bag: 30F Down
review.reviewBody:
The Riff 30 hits the sweet spot. Great price. Great Quality. Packability. I went with the 30 because it packs down small enough to work with my bikepacking setup. If and when I need more warmth, I wear a puffy jacket and some thermal bottoms. 

The bag has very little down on the backside (bottom) so you need a good (warm) pad like the Nemo Tensor. I personally use the Quasar 3D and a Nemo Fillo. I don't sacrifice my sleep system. I'm happy to save weight elsewhere but if I don't sleep, I don't ride well the next day. 

It's all a compromise but I've never been let down by Nemo products. This bag packs pretty small and for side-sleepers like me, I wouldn't trade it. I've used the tight mummy bags and HATE them. I've not tried quilts yet because there's just something about tossing a bag on a pad and going to bed. No fussing with pad straps or draw cords in my face. 

I love the pillow sleeve inside too. The ONLY thing that would be really cool on future bags is a pad sleeve to keep the bag from moving around but that's just a selfish wish. I love the bag as is. I don't abuse my gear so I hope it will last me many years and accompany me on many more adventures.  Thanks, Nemo friends!
review.name: Love my Riff 30. Love Nemo

review.itemreviewed: Riff Endless Promise 30 Sleeping Bag: 30F Down
review.reviewBody: I was extremely excited about my new bag until I opened the box and found the bottom of the bags stitching had come loose.  I returned the bag and received a full refund.
review.name: DISSAPPOINTMENT

review.itemreviewed: Riff Endless Promise 30 Sleeping Bag: 30F Down
review.reviewBody:
I was immediately unimpressed by this bag. You can tell within seconds that it doesnt stack up to other bags at this cost point. The down has a pathetic amount of loft and honestly, the shape further contributes to it not stacking up to its temp rating. I used it on 4 separate trips, all with lows in the mid 40s and was incredible uncomfortable. I have used many other 30deg bags and have never really been disappointed by one until now.

Note: this review is regarding the previous version. Based on specs (fill weight, dimensions) I doubt its any better now though.
review.name: 30 degrees, more like 50
comment: Thank you for the feedback! I'm sorry to hear that you found the sleeping bag to be cold. It's very important to consider the whole sleep system. The ISO Test used to determine sleeping bag ratings involves placing a heavily instrumented electronic manikin, dressed in long underwear, inside the sleeping bag being tested, and positioning on top of a foam sleeping pad. Campers will want to make sure they are dressed for the temps and using a sleeping pad to accompany the sleeping bag. This blog we have about understanding sleeping bag temperature ratings is a wealth of information, https://www.nemoequipment.com/blogs/journal/decoding-sleeping-bag-temperature-ratings Thanks again for the feedback.

review.itemreviewed: Riff Endless Promise 30 Sleeping Bag: 30F Down
review.reviewBody: Packs small, super light, and soooo roomy! I love this bag. The thermo gills are great on warmer nights too!
review.name: Amazing bag

review.itemreviewed: Riff Endless Promise 30 Sleeping Bag: 30F Down
review.reviewBody: Got this bag for multi season raft trips.  Was very comfortable for spring and summer adventures.  Looking forward to using it again this spring on the Upper Colorado!
review.name: Great bag for raft trips

review.itemreviewed: Riff Endless Promise 30 Sleeping Bag: 30F Down
review.reviewBody: I purchased the 15 degree to have an in between warmth rating that could be used on winter hut trips and higher elevation/fall backpacking. This bag is lightweight and VERY comfortable.  All of the additional features are useful and I will be purchasing nemo bags only gojng forward!
review.name: Exceptional Bag

review.itemreviewed: Riff Endless Promise 30 Sleeping Bag: 30F Down
review.reviewBody: First use was in in freezing conditions, so warm I had to open the vents! great bag.
review.name: Crazy Warm

review.itemreviewed: Riff Endless Promise 30 Sleeping Bag: 30F Down
review.reviewBody: After 20 years of refusing to give up a good ole sleeping bag... I didn't realize what I missing out on.
review.name: Why did I wait?

review.itemreviewed: Riff Endless Promise 30 Sleeping Bag: 30F Down
review.reviewBody: Warm, packs small, excellent fit and finish.  10 out of 10 would recommend it to a friend!
review.name: Fantastic
